boardgame.name: Crypt X
boardgame.description:
Crypt X is a narrative puzzle game, following the mystery of a missing archaeology professor. After his curious absence at a dig near Luxor, you began to investigate the notes he left behind. As his student, you must piece together the puzzles in his file to discover more about his work and where he is now.

Solve ciphers and codes, identify patterns and combine clues to uncover the professor’s secrets. Answering each of the fifty-one puzzles unlocks a new section of narrative in the Crypt X companion app, unraveling the story surrounding his disappearance. Each puzzle contributes to your score, depending on the number of hints used and attempts made. Your total score will determine the ending to the professor’s story - can you find the secrets hidden deep within Crypt X?

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Kaiju Stadium
boardgame.description:
Kaiju Stadium is a two-player strategy game about giant monsters playing sports. In it, you make use of dice, play cards, and unique kaiju abilities to pull off wild combinations and score points against your opponent.

Each turn, you roll two dice and pick from them to decide what you're going to do with that turn. The dice give you movement options, let you kick the ball, and more, plus you have access to limited-use Play cards that let you do things that aren't on the dice. Beyond that, every kaiju has a pair of unique special abilities: one that modifies how it interacts with the basic rules of the game (e.g. Hyperion can trample through opposing kaiju while moving) and one that happens when they switch onto the field from the sidelines (e.g. Nimbus can steal the ball from a nearby space). You're going to spend each turn making decisions about who to move, who to have on the field, and what to do with your kaiju, trying to solve the ongoing puzzle of "can I score a point this turn or not?"

Get the ball into the opponent's goal to score a point. The game is over when a player can reach three or more points with a two point lead or when either play reaches five points.

Rounds take about 15-30 minutes and the game rarely unfolds the exact same way twice, so the game is meant to be played several times in a row.

boardgame.name: Brexit: The Board Game of Second Chances
boardgame.description:
Brexit: The Board Game of Second Chances is a dice-rolling, strategic-token placement game that is easy to learn, but provides depth for experienced gamers. It is also steeped in parody--both through artwork and flavor text--concerning the EU Referendum. Whether you supported Leave, Remain, or just like to see political figures taken to task, there’s something here for you to laugh about. (There’s also fact cards, with actual facts relevant to the issues of the EU Referendum…ones neither campaign seemed to actually use.)

In a Nutshell:
Each player chooses a campaign (Leave or Remain) then cooperates with that campaign to defeat the other campaign. There are two primary game mechanics: (1) rolling dice to match symbols on cards that provide effects, and (2) using those effects to strategically place campaign tokens on a map (or remove your opponents). The campaign that claims a majority of the map first, wins. Players can also use effects to sabotage the opposing campaign.

A Player's Turn:
A player rolls argument dice and tries to match the symbols on the dice (representing arguments relevant to the EU Referendum) with the symbols on headline cards. Matching all the symbols on a headline card grants the player various effects--from advancing the player's side on the map (and thus winning over voters) to sabotaging another player (by blocking that player from rerolling, using wilds, or advancing that player's side on the map).

The campaign that flips three of the five voting regions first--by placing three tokens on a region or through other game effects--wins the vote and the game.

Brexit: The Board Game of Second Chances provides humorous content with accessible, quick-to-learn, but dynamic gameplay. It's perfect for a mix of skilled and new gamers, or as a fun distraction on an otherwise long and serious gaming session.

boardgame.name: Tactic All Stars Coach Collectible Card Game
boardgame.description:
In this collectible card game players take the role of the soccer team managers.

Each player is given 6000 currency to spent on players for their team. The same player may not be chosen twice.

After the teams have been chosen it is time to play soccer. Each player has their own board where they put their player cards. Both players start with a ball on their goal keepper. The ball is moved by rolling a dice and players do so in turn. With 1-2 the ball goes backwards, 3 sideways and 4-6 forward. If the ball can't move back it stays where it is.

When a player gets the ball to attacking zone a kick occurs. The attacking player throws the dice again and adds the value to the kickers attack value. Defending player checks the defending value of the goalkeeper and the player of his who has the ball and counts them together. If the attacker has a bigger sum the kick is a goal, and if defending sum is bigger the game continues.

The game ends when an agreed number of goals is made.

This is basically a two player game, but can be plaid with multiple people as a tournament.

boardgame.name: Pääministeri-peli
boardgame.description:
The box comes with two games.

First is Pääministeri-peli where players compete to be the prime minister of Finland.

Players roll dice in turn order to move on a map of Finland. And they try to collect as many votes as possible until some one finds the voting token and manages to get it back to Helsinki.

When moving around the map, players turn around tokens from which they either get or lose votes.

When the voting token is returned to Helsinki, everyone counts their votes and who ever has the most is the winner.

The second game Ministeri Mylly is basically Trouble/Kimble, but with a twist.

Each player has two pieces. Pieces are moved on a round track by trowing a dice. Players try to get their peaces around the board. When they do they become ministers, and are moved to ministry. From there they might be forced to go to European Parliament.

The player that has the prime minister or otherwise highest ranking ministers is the winner.

—user summary

boardgame.name: Prime Number Lv.0
素数大富豪 Lv.0 (Prime Daifugo Lv.0)
boardgame.description:
In Prime Number Lv.0, a.k.a. 素数大富豪 Lv.0, prime numbers meet Daifugo, the most popular climbing game in Japan, resulting in a Daifugo game with a twist. Prime Number Lv.0 is a re-implementation of 素数大富豪 (Prime Daifugo) with changes made for easier play and for the incorporation of hand management during the game.

Shuffle the deck, then deal ten cards to each player. The leader plays any prime number from a combination of 1-3 cards (see below), then in clockwise order, players may pass or play a larger prime number than the most recently played prime using the same number of cards as the leader. (A player can optionally draw a card from the deck prior to playing.) The round continues until no player wants to play. The last player who played a valid number leads the next round. If you get rid of all cards in your hand, you win the round and whoever first wins two rounds wins the game.

To play a prime number, take 1-3 cards from your hand and arrange them to create a single number by using all the digits on those cards. If the number is prime, your play is valid. For example, if playing "3" and "5", you may arrange their order and play them only as "53" because "35" is not a prime number. To play three cards, all of the cards must have single digits on them (so you can't use "10" or "12") and at least one of the cards must feature a "play three" icon.

•••

素数と大富豪と素数の素敵な出会い！
普通の大富豪とは一味違ったゲームです。

元々トランプゲームで遊ばれていた「素数大富豪」をより遊びやすくアレンジしたものです。
遊びやすくなっただけでなく、ハンドマネジメントによるゲーム性がより高いものに進化しています！

【ルール概要】
各プレイヤー10枚のカードが配られた状態でゲームが始まります。
大富豪と同じように、プレイヤーがカードをプレイする時、親が出した枚数と同じ枚数で、かつ前のプレイヤーが出した数字よりも大きい数字をプレイする必要があります。手札を全て出し切ったプレイヤーが勝利です。
通常の大富豪と違う点、それは「プレイするカードが素数でなくてはならない」ということです。
複数枚のカードをプレイする場合はその数字を並べたものが、プレイした数字となります。例えば 3 と 7 をプレイすると決めた場合。
1枚目を3、2枚目を5とすれば「35」になり
1枚目を5、2枚目を3とすれば「53」になります。
この場合35は素数ではないので、53としてプレイすることになります。

その他細かいルールもあるので詳しくは説明書を見てください。
（2018年11月現在、英語版の説明書は作成中です）

boardgame.name: Handuł: Kupcy z Wilamowic
boardgame.description:
"Handuł" ("Trade") is an educational board game about merchants from Wilamowce - unique town in southern Poland, known for the endangered language Wymysiöeryś.

The players line up their pawns in front of the shops, marketplace, and town hall to purchase local goods and export them to distant austro-hungarian cities. Instead of paying for merchandise cards, players can lock their pawns on cards until the price is payed. Each transaction requires shipment - players can build their own transport route, or simply pay other players to use their carriage.

Game ends after 5 to 8 rounds and player with the most money wins.

During the game players can learn words from Wymysiöeryś language and see traditional Wilamowiceans' outfit.

-description from designer

boardgame.name: The War of the Orcses: Mass Battle Rules for the Orc Civil Wars
The Wars of the Orcses: Mass Battle Rules for the Orc Civil Wars
boardgame.description:
These rules describe an often overlooked period of warfare known as the Wars of the Orcses, a civil war between competing factions in the northern regions of Orcland. The war was fought between two rival branches of the House of Plantagut: the House of Lank-Pasta, associated with the emblem of the red rose growing out of the skull of a dead Angry-Vin Goblin – and the House of Yorc whose symbol was the white rose (growing out of the arse of a dead Stu-Wart Goblin). The wars lasted for over thirty years with many epic battles fought including the Battles of Stained Albans, Pewksebery and many many more. The struggle swung back and forth with first one faction in the ascendancy and then the other. The heavy loss of Orc life was both widespread and tragic – and neighbouring powers looked on with interest as Orcland seemed to tear itself apart. Eventually the war ended at the decisive Battle of Bogsworth Field and the crowning of the warlord Hen-Wee as king Hen-Wee VII. The kings position was further strengthened when Hen-Wee married Elibarf of Yorc, the daughter of Edturd IV, the most prominent Yorcist claimant to the throne of Orcland.

The Wars of the Orcses rules allow players to fight large scale battles between rival Orc armies with lots of supporting allied and mercenary units of Goblins, Hobgoblins, Trolls and Ogres. The rules included a detailed background to the conflict, the key players and a list of the major battles fought. Also included is a scenario describing the Battle of Pewksbery. If you fancy a bit of Orc on Orc action you probably need help – but either way these are the rules for you!

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: The Pyrabec Game
boardgame.description:
Essentially a roll and move game.

The game board consists of a 3D plastic pyramid with a track running around the outside. This track is indented to hold marbles in place. Some of the spaces have holes which drop the marble to lower levels of the pyramid. Each player has 3 marbles which they have to get to the top of the pyramid. Roll the die to determine how many spaces your marble can move and try to avoid the holes.

The first player to get all three marbles to the top is the winner.

—user summary

boardgame.name: Civilization 6 - Gathering Storm
Civilization VI - Gathering Storm
Civilization VI: Gathering Storm
boardgame.description:
The world around you is more alive than ever in Civilization VI: Gathering Storm, the second expansion to the award-winning grand strategy game, Sid Meier’s Civilization VI.

Launching for Windows PC on February 14, 2019, Civilization VI: Gathering Storm adds new advanced technologies, engineering projects, the fan-favorite World Congress, and introduces a living world ecosystem that showcases natural events that could enrich or challenge your growing empire. Civilization VI: Gathering Storm also adds eight new civilizations and nine new leaders, seven new World Wonders, and a variety of new units, districts, buildings, improvements and more.

Source: The Game Website.

boardgame.name: Bologna 1945
boardgame.description:
The Battle of Bologna, fought in April 1945, was the last battle of the Polish 2nd Corps. It was the end of the Second World War, however, Germans were not eager to surrender, especially to the Poles. They defended each of their positions fiercely, often using mines and traps. But the determined attack of the Polish soldiers freed Bologna, ending the combat trail of the Polish forces in Italy.

This game uses Taktyka i Strategia's 2nd World War "WB95" system. The game is in Polish, but translations of the rules are available form the publisher and are made available upon request (if they are not sent right away).

boardgame.name: Rise of Kings
boardgame.description:
5 POPULATIONS. 4 NATIONS, 2 GAME MODES, 1 KING This board game is set in the Medieval Northern Europe and is a fusion of several board games and video games that have made the history of entertainment. It consists of over 900 pieces including soldiers, officers, relics, constructions and dices as well as an IOS and ANDROID APP.

The object of the game is to become the King of the Empire subduing other population in a economical war. Choose your population and, turn after turn, evolve to unlock features that will allow you to attack your enemies more effectively and move through land and sea faster. Conquer territories, capitals and relics on the gameboard, earn points in the APP and evolve to subdue the other population.

—description from the designer

boardgame.name: Yu-Gi-Oh! TCG: Structure Deck – Powercode Link
boardgame.description:
This is the 42nd Deck in the TCG's Structure Deck series.

Create brand new Link Summoning combinations with Yu-Gi-Oh! TRADING CARD GAME Structure Deck: Powercode Link! This Deck features a new “Code Talker” Link Monster plus LINK-2 and LINK-3 monsters you can Summon using any monsters, and whose Link Arrows all point to your own Main Monster Zones!

Yu-Gi-Oh! TRADING CARD GAME Structure Deck: Powercode Link is a great second step for Duelists who started Dueling with Yu-Gi-Oh! TRADING CARD GAME Starter Deck: Codebreaker. Co-Link your Transcode Talker from Yu-Gi-Oh! TRADING CARD GAME Starter Deck: Codebreaker with Powercode Talker to boost both monsters by 500 ATK and make them untargetable by opposing card effects! The added protection helps keep Powercode Talker ready to make double-powered attacks every turn.

Finally, for Duelists that like to live dangerously, a new Field Spell gives you a chance to Special Summon a random Cyberse-Type Link Monster directly from your Extra Deck without having to Link Summon or use any monsters as Materials. But to claim that reward, you have to take 2000 or more damage from one battle or card effect, simulating Playmaker’s “Storm Access” skill from the animated series!


Each Structure Deck contains:


38 Common Cards, 2 Ultra Rare Cards, 3 Super Rare Cards, 1 Beginner‘s Guide and 1 Double-sided Deluxe Game Mat/Dueling Guide


—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Squadron Strike: Traveller
boardgame.description:
In the tradition of Squadron Strike, this boxed set is a complete game released after a Kickstarter fulfillment of 2 years.

The Wars of the Third Imperium are handled in High Guard for large fleet actions. There are plenty of other battles that require a finer scale with more detail per ship, and Squadron Strike: Traveller provides that detail, while bringing Traveller space combat into fully realized 3D vector movement.

The boxed set contains everything you need to play Traveller ships in the Squadron Strike engine.

boardgame.name: Samolub w kosmosie
Selfish: Space Edition
boardgame.description:
How far would you go to save yourself? Totally selfish behaviour and utter ruthlessness will be needed to stay alive in this game!

Only one astronaut can get home on the remaining oxygen supplies and you must battle against wormholes, asteroid fields, laser blasts and most dangerous of all, each other, to win!

Full of clever puns and pop culture references, this ruthless strategy card game includes 5 player cards, 1 spaceship card, 42 space cards, 48 oxygen cards, 30 game cards, a place marker and instructions.

—description from the publisher

Each astronaut starts with a hand of 5 Game Cards which contain a mixture of Oxygen and Action Cards.
On your turn, pick up a card from the Game card pile which is formed of Action cards and Oxygen. Action cards allow you to attack other players by stealing precious Oxygen, moving them back a space or shielding yourself from other players attacks! You can then use your Oxygen cards to move forward through the dangerous void of space. Each time you move forward you reveal a space card which can help or harm you!
Get back to the ship first to win, but remember to keep enough oxygen or you'll die...

boardgame.name: 100 Fantasy Maps to Find
boardgame.description:
Publisher Blurb:

Maps are often a staple in fantasy settings. They are how characters find places and can provided needed clues. This is a collection of 100 different maps that can be dropped into a game. They can be used to enliven an existing, but boring, map, as a source of potential adventure hooks or simply as background colour and red herrings.

The maps come in a variety of different types, from paper and vellum to stranger types such as metal, magical or simply odd. Some may not be easily identifiable as maps, at least to start with.

This PDF supports Adobe layers and the page backgrounds and images can be disabled to make printing easier.

Here is a sample result:

Dome - A dome made from hammered bronze that measures 2’ in diameter. The outside of the dome is plain and slightly tarnished. Inside the dome various semi-precious stones of different sizes and in a few shades of red, white and blue colours have been placed in mounts. These stones are joined by lines engraved into the bronze that make them into individual, discrete patterns, ranging in size and shape. The semi-precious stones signify stars, with the sizes and colours related to the colour of the stars and their brightness. The etched lines join the stars together into constellations, although unfamiliar ones.

One page is the cover and one the front matter.

boardgame.name: Król Popiel
boardgame.description:
Old polish legend says that a swarm of mice had emerged from the Goplo lake and eaten evil king Popiel as a punishment for his malicious reign.
In this game the players alternately place mice tiles on the Kruszwica tower, where Popiel fled. The better the tile fits on the board, the more points it scores. If tile touches Popiel's pawn, player gets random bonus (another move, points multiplier etc.), and evil king retreats to upper foors. Game ends when he can flee no more. The player with the most points wins.

—user summary

boardgame.name: Winterborne
boardgame.description:
Winterborne is a Euro-style medium weight game with light deckbuilding and tableau building. Players will use three different characters; the Viking, the Shaman, and the Explorer to lead their clan and expand their kingdom. The game is played over the Norse calendar year and each clan is preparing for the harsh winter. Players will enjoy the light interaction by exploring for cards and conquering nearby lands. Once winter is over the game ends and the player with the most Victory Points wins the game.

Winterborne has multiple paths to victory and each player can decide the best route based on card collection, expanding and settling, or trading with allies. Each path provides a rich and enjoyable play.

—description from the publisher

A REALM OF PRIMITIVE ADVENTURE...

The Living Land is ruled by High Lord Baruk Kaah and his army of reptilian edeinos. It has taken over both coasts of the United States, the Yucatan Peninsula in Mexico, and the mysterious "White Zone" in Canada.

Where the Living Land rules miraculous power is available, but technology rusts and fails. Ordinary humans--and even some heroes--regress and become ruled by their primal passions.

There are amazing opportunities scattered among the Living Land's perils. The Law of Wonders insures that lost treasures appear in the misty and unexplored jungles. boardgame.name: Dortoka: City on the Sea of Glass
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:



Plunder the dead metropolis on the Sea of Glass in this OSR urban toolkit and setting guide

Dortoka: City on the Sea of Glass is a city-building toolkit and adventure module designed to work with Vagabonds of Dyfed. Because of its origin, it’s semi-compatible with most OSR systems (such as B/X and Labyrinth Lord) and PbtA games (such as Dungeon World).

Inspired by magical post-apocalyptic settings like Dark Sun mixed with fantastical and wild cities like Doskvol, Dortoka is a compact supplement that lets you build your own incomprehensibly massive fallen metropolis.

As a product built for Vagabonds, it comes with additional mechanics -- a new lineage, new techniques, and guidelines on psionics. While made for a specific game in mind, these rules are easy to port into your game of choice.


Vagabonds Stuff

The first chunk of the book focuses on how to incorporate Dortoka (or Dark Sun inspired cities) into your campaign, especially for those playing Vagabonds or similar games.

Basics and intro: evocative details, a brief write up, and tips on how to bring Dortoka into a new or existing game
Psionics: a combination of rules and setting information; psionics play a key role in Dortoka and the surrounding Sea of Glass. Guidelines on how to acquire and use psionic powers, how they can go wrong, and what they might cost an unwary psion who opened their mind too greedily
A new lineage, the Hozka: an insectoid people inspired by Thri-Kreen and Formics, this species has a tenuous hive-mind, latent psionic abilities, and impressive strength
New techniques: short and punchy special abilities not unlike spells or feats in other systems
Dortokan enemies: a handful of setting-specific monster stat blocks for Dortokan bad guys (including a demonically possessed dragon and the glass-and-steel constructs left behind by the Dortokan Mind Lords)




City Building Toolkit

The rest of the book’s all about how you can build your version of Dortoka as you play. Each section has tables, examples, and tips to make the best out of your time:

Organizational structure: a quick outline to help you mentally (or physically) map out Dortoka, splitting things into distinct wards and blocks
Randomizing streets, blocks, and landmarks: a system for quickly randomizing a cartographic view of a block or a few streets. Likewise, you can generate key areas in a given region (and how hotly contested they are)
The city as a pointcrawl: advice and techniques for running a city-exploration game as a pointcrawl; focusing on points of interest and the routes connecting them
Tables and tables and tables: descriptor tables, bits of inspirational details, color-palettes, themes, and adventure seeds for each “class” of ward (from warrens to palatial)
Six sample wards: a complete (albeit unmapped) ward for each class including key resources, population, and details




Factions

While the city’s all but empty -- the once invincible Dortokan Empire is mostly peopled by ghosts now -- hundreds of factions scrape together a living in the psychic mirage of a wasteland that is the City on the Sea of Glass.

Organization randomization: twelve tables to randomize every aspect of a faction from how it’s structured to its armament and current struggles
Details: as with cities, details and inspiration for factions that the GM can plop in at will
Rumors: a rumor table related to each type of faction, setting up encounters, adventure arcs, or quests
NPC tables: quick NPCs on the go, name generators, and all manner of people-specific descriptions
Six sample factions: organization, structure, territory, goals, and resources to easily insert into your game

Oh no ? The villains have escaped. Help Christians to catch them. Roll the colored dice, and catch the fast and cunning villains. The more you catch, the better. Excitement for the whole family.

The player ending with the most pairs of villains win.

boardgame.description:
ベビーカーでGO! (Go with the Stroller!) is a simple co-operative card game in which the players are all moms out with their strollers and need to reach the goal.

Each turn, the player draws a card, then plays one. A go! card makes the player advance. A trouble card is played in front of any player and blocks that player from advancing. Troubles can be overcome by a die roll or playing a help card.

Once all moms have advanced ten steps, the players win. Otherwise they lose.

It's a race to collect the fruit as you roll the die and move around the "screen" just like the video game. But look out for the ghosts, Blinky, Pinky, Inky and Clyde! They'll try to get in your way and keep you from moving around the board and collecting your fruit.
—description from the publisher

Pac-Man Maze Craze was a Wendy's Kids' Meal giveaway based on the classic video game. Players roll a special die to move around a board representing the Pac-Man screen and collect a designated number of fruit tokens. Landing on a ghost token ends a player's turn and blocks a path. Rolling a ghost on the die causes loss of a fruit token. First player to return to the start with the right number of tokens wins.

—user summary

boardgame.name: Ruins Raiders
boardgame.description:
Imagine a cooperative exploration game in the tradition of Indiana Jones with a "lite" blend of a good ol' fashioned dungeon crawl using modular tiles and deadly traps.

It even has a light battle mechanic, so players can choose whether to work together or to betray their friends in their quest to escape alive with the master treasure chest. Players will take turns moving through the dungeon, building it as they go, and using up to 3 actions each turn. Traps spring up randomly, as do monsters... and glorious treasure. Treasure cards reveal bonuses to movement and combat. At any point a player may decide to attack another player and escape alone with the treasure, becoming the only winner at the table.

And the best part is, all the mechanics work well either in large groups, small groups, or even solo.

It's a "lite" tabletop roleplaying game with a very basic dungeon crawl that can be done co-op, solo, or even versus.

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Dice Fight: Chicken Edition
boardgame.description:
Dice Fight: Chicken Edition is a fun, quick-moving, easy-to-learn, light strategy game. Players can learn how to play in three minutes and finish the game in about 20 minutes.

Players each begin with 10 unique chickens and 10 cards. In each round, players present a chicken to the dice fight, roll dice simultaneously, then send losing chickens to the fried-chicken carry-out bucket. But before sending a losing chicken to the bucket, players will determine whether or not to play a card that can alter the outcome of the dice roll.
Players will fall in love with the adorable chickens and become heartbroken when their favorites are tragically sent to the carry-out bucket. But if you play your cards right and get just a little bit of luck from the dice, it will be winner winner chicken dinner!

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Murder at Tara
boardgame.description:
Murder at Tara, An ACOS Gay Game. A Role-Playing Murder Mystery game for eight Adults.

MURDER AT TARA
Someone murdered Villain Legree, that scoundrel scalawag who was determined to steal Tara from poor Miss Harlot O'Hara by raising her taxes sky high. Villain used to be the cruel overseer at Tara, but now he's just dead.
It's up to you and your guests to discover who murdered Villain Legree - and why.

THE SUSPECTS
Harlot O'Hara --- beautiful owner of Tara Plantation. Since Villain saw her without her dress, it was curtains for her. People thought she was sweet on Lark Gaybelle, but perhaps everything was not as it seemed at Tara
Lark Gaybelle --- handsome stranger, hired to build a levee across Tara's lowland to help prevent the pasture from flooding. A dapper man, never without this spats and gold-handled walking cane, he made more than one's heart throb at Tara.
Butterfly the Queen ---- Miss Harlot's personal srvant. Flighty as his name, he was always there to lay out Miss Harlot's clothes -- and sometimes her beaux.
Leslie Coward --- the owner of the elegant neighboring plantation, Thirteen Oaks, and Oblivion's husband. Bespectacled and nervous as a mouse on a hot tin cat, he was afraid of his own shadow - especially one dark shadow from his past.
Oblivion Dehavilland, sweet wife of Leslie Coward. Oblivion, poor dear, was a bit forgetful since the onset of mental pause.
Rough and Ready the Tarlton Twins, fro the neighboring plantation, Fetish Hall. They were wild and kinky guys, and their lives were somehow entwined with poor dead Villain Legree. They both had meaningful relationships with various animals, vegetables, minerals, and sometimes even humans.
Mammy Dearest, Tara's faithful servant. She stalked the halls of Tara with her padded shoulders, serving Pepsi and True Grits in Southern style. She knew most of Tara's dark secrets, and she had a few dark secrets of her own.

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Dice & Danger: Dragon's Lair
boardgame.description:
The dragon Firethrax has left his lair to take a bath in a nearby lake, leaving his treasure unguarded. Your band of adventurers teleports to his treasure to claim it, but you must evade traps and battle monsters to escape. Just when you think you have reached the exit, Firethrax returns to stop you! Which adventurer among you will defeat the dragon to claim victory?

Dice & Danger: Dragon's Lair is a board game designed to introduce younger children to the basic concepts of fantasy role-playing games. It is a simple race game in which players try to be the first to defeat the dragon at the last space on the board. Players take on the roles of various fantasy characters and start the game with three treasure cards, which allow them to perform actions or add to their combat die roll. A ten-sided die determines movement and combat. The spaces on the board are either free spaces or encounter spaces. The encounter spaces can be traps, monsters, or the single Holy Fountain treasure space. The monsters become progressively more difficult to defeat along the track, culminating in Firethrax the dragon. Defeating a monster rewards the player with a new treasure card, but losing to a monster means losing the next turn. The first player to defeat Firethrax wins the game.

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Hammer and Nails: A Card Tile Game
boardgame.description:
Basics of Hammer and Nails – A Card Tile Game

Competing players take turns constructing a dynamic Build Stack using cards played from their hand. The objective is to have the fewest number of total Nails, including visible Nails on the Build Stack at the end of the game.

Players tactically stack the cards which produce interesting outcomes for placement of their opponents' cards. Typically, Players have 4 cards in hand, plays one per turn and draws or discards cards at end of their turn.

The rule set, percentages of mechanics, and location of the Hammers and Nails have been designed to provide a challenge and encourage players to engage in tactical thinking. The format and rules engine allows any level of experience an opportunity to enjoy a competitive game, however the game scales in it's competitive nature as players advance and formulate their adaptive play style during a game.

Welcome to the unique competitive Build Stack of Card Tiles!

—description from the designer

boardgame.name: Dicehack
boardgame.description: The Node protects some of the corporate worlds most valuable information, but a group of hackers has found a backdoor. Be the first to exploit this weakness and gain access to the treasures of the Node. Other hackers are hot on your heels, so you'll have to bring all your talents to bear. Each player in Dicehack is competing against the others. Games take 45-60 minutes, depending on the number of players. The player boards provide nearly all the reference information you'll need to play. Game play is a combination of wagering resources, luck of the roll, and strategy in capturing, attacking, and defending. Players roll dice and try to add or multiply them to unlock a series of spaces in the Fibonacci Sequence. Math is not for everyone, but you can win at Dicehack using the calculator on your smartphone. You'll wager the number of dice you'll need to open spaces on your board, to attack other players and set them back, to protect your own spaces from attack, and to allow you to change faces on other dice. You'll choose your targets, use your number skills, and manage your resources. The first player that unlocks all eight spaces on their board wins the game.

boardgame.name: The Door to Everywhere
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

The Door to Everywhere is a 60-character PLANESCAPE freeform designed to run over two 3-hour sessions. These two game sessions can be on different days; before and after lunch; or blended together, depending on the needs and desires of Game Masters and players.

It is recommended that The Door to Everywhere be run by a group of six or more Game Masters, all of whom should be at least familiar with the basics of PLANESCAPE. Previous experience with Live Action Roleplaying and Freeforming is desirable but not necessary. For a game of this size, it is vitally important that all of the Game Masters be organised and informed of how the game is being run. It is also important that one of the Game Masters keeps everything flowing smoothly and keeps track of the game as a whole. This “primary GM” should be familiar with every detail of the freeform.

User summary:

This complex scenario is distributed as two ZIP archives (with largely redundant file structures) containing dozens of files of various formats.

boardgame.name: Red Sunset
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

Throughout 1998, tensions between Iraq and the West have been escalating. Led by the United States, teams of UN inspectors attempted to determine whether Saddam Hussein had been developing biological weapons of mass destruction since the Gulf War of 1991. No solid evidence was discovered; however, paranoia remained high as Iraqi soldiers refused the UN teams access to some locations. On the 22nd of September, 1998, such suspicions were shown to be well-founded.

Apparently in response to a European Economic Union decision to impose further economic sanctions on Iraq, missiles exploded over many of the cities of Europe. Bucharest. Stockholm. Bonn. London. Ankara. Rome.

On the first day, people across Europe woke to the booming of missiles exploding overhead.

By noon on the second day, thousands were suffering from pounding headaches and hot flushes. By midnight these people were also complaining of severe cramps and blood in their bodily wastes. The evening news declared that the water supply of many cities had been contaminated by an unknown pathogen.

By sunset on the third day, the victims of Iraq's biological weapon were suffering from haemorrhages and open wounds all over their body. The blood refused to clot; most bled to death by morning. Newspapers and TVs screamed a name for this disease, a name coined by a Fleet Street tabloid: the Sunset Plague.

User summary:

The scenario is distributed as four ZIP Archives, each expanding into several documents of various formats.
